#Text=4.
#Text=The Public Purpose/Public Interest Requirement in South African Law
#Text=Section 25(2 ) of the South African Constitution of 1996 only permits an expropriation for a public purpose or in the public interest and based on laws of general application .
#Text=Section 2(1 ) of the Expropriation Act empowers the Minister of Public Works to expropriate property for public purposes .
#Text=The first part of the following analysis discusses the definition of ‘ public purpose ’ and ‘ public interest ’ in South African law .

#Text=The second part then analyses the extent to which the legislature and the courts define ‘ public purpose ’ and ‘ public interest ’ , and the remaining discretion of the competent authority to define the expropriation ’s purpose .
#Text=The third part evaluates whether South African law complies with VGGT 16.1 .
#Text=4.1. The Definition of ‘ Public Purpose ’ and ‘ Public Interest ’
#Text=In the pre-constitutional era , under the Apartheid regime , until the Interim Constitution entered into force in 1993 , expropriation was only possible for a ‘ public purpose ’ .
#Text=The courts defined ‘ public purposes ’ as all purposes that pertain to and benefit the public ( in contradistinction to private individuals ) .
#Text=This definition is very abstract and appears to cover an endless variety of purposes .

#Text=Accordingly , the courts approved expropriations for the security and privacy of the Prime Minister , urban development , the maintenance of the national telecommunication system , the preservation of vegetation , and the maintenance of water quality .

#Text=A project even served a public purpose if it only indirectly contributed to these purposes , for instance through the provision of housing for technicians who would then maintain the telecommunication system .

#Text=In the famous Van Streepen judgment , Smalberger JA held that also the ‘ public interest ’ could justify an expropriation and found that while it did not serve a public purpose , even the private supply of strategically important products served a public interest that could justify an expropriation .
#Text=Only projects that solely benefited private individuals could not justify an expropriation .
#Text=With the constitutional era came new uncertainties .
#Text=The definition of the newly introduced ‘ public interest ’ remains unclear ; Section 25(4)(a ) of the Constitution only clarifies that property may be expropriated for land reform purposes .

#Text=What seems settled is that ‘ public purpose ’ is a narrower category that in its entirety forms part of the greater category ‘ public interest ’ , and that the drafters of the Constitution intended to provide a broad constitutional authorisation for expropriation .
#Text=The Constitutional Court has yet to provide clarity on the meaning of ‘ public purpose ’ and ‘ public interest ’ .
#Text=To shed light on the meaning of these terms this sub-section analyses the applicable jurisprudence of the High Court and the Supreme Court of Appeal .
#Text=As both public purposes and the public interest can justify an expropriation , this contribution does not deal with the distinction between these two terms any further .

#Text=The analysis shows that the courts have adopted the abstract definition of ‘ public purpose ’ from the pre-constitutional era and construe ‘ public purpose ’ and ‘ public interest ’ very broadly .
#Text=Even indirect economic benefits of private business projects may validly justify an expropriation .
#Text=In eThekwini Municipality v Sotirios Spetsiotis , the KwaZulu-Natal High Court decided that an upgrade of the Durban beachfront for the 2010 soccer World Cup constituted a public purpose .
#Text=Urban development for a global sports event is thus a public purpose .

#Text=While the upgrade could still directly benefit the public through the improvement of private infrastructure , Bartsch Consult ( Pty ) Limited v Mayoral Committee of the Maluti-A-Phofung Municipality concerned the construction of a private shopping complex .
#Text=Ebrahim J considered for the Free State High Court that it was the responsibility of the municipalities to ensure their economic viability and prevent rising unemployment and poverty .

#Text=He found that the shopping complex would provide strategic economic advantages to the municipality in the form of greater financial returns , which would then result in a healthier and wealthier environment .
#Text=Therefore , Ebrahim J held the shopping complex to be in the public interest .
